Although San Diego's boss skill description says every 18s, it is actually approximately 17.15s, 19.2s, 18.15s, then repeat. Set a margin and call them 17s, 19s, and 18s for safety. This slight 1 second difference is important because if your main fleet is between 17 and 18s, it may be caught by San Diego's 17s cycle, which could desync your whole main fleet.

San Diego always teleports to the same position, which happens to be close enough to activate Friedrich der Große's proximity barrage, giving her consistent damage every boss cycle. This interaction increases FdG's viability by a lot in this battle, taking her from the bottom tier of rainbow BBs to somewhere in the middle of rainbow BBs. The teleport destination is just over 65 units from the flagship, so the flagship's secondary guns can also do a bit of damage.
After teleporting, the boss stays still for 2s, then starts zooming around and gets +20% eva rate.
So it's not good for your main fleet to fire after the teleport

, because she will dodge a lot of damage with both speed and evasion. If BBs fire just before the teleport, then 1 out of 3 volleys may hit the water when the boss teleports. If CVs launch airstrikes just before the teleport, then a lot of damage is lost because the teleport destination is too close for rocket fighters to aim at most of the time.

The "special stage" gives +20% EVA RATE, not +20% EVA as claimed by the game. Also, it lasts for 8s, not 5s. This bug doesn't change the strategies, but it is always interesting to note bugs, and it makes the battle slightly harder than the boss skill descriptions would imply.

Say your ship's weapon has a reload progress going from 0% to 100%. If San Diego sings when your ship is at 100%, nothing happens. Otherwise, 15%, 20%, or 30% is subtracted from the reload progress depending on its type. Reload progress cannot go below 0%. So if your ship fires just before San Diego sings, her reload progress will go from like 1% to 0%, which is effectively no loss in reload time and DPS. This changes the balance of power between the HE guns.
Note: Vanguard DDG missiles are not part of the torpedo, gun, or airstrike manual queues, so they are not affected.

For the purposes of this strategy discussion, we will assume you are using three BBs (add 30% reload time) because they are easiest to understand and use in this battle. There are several brackets of interest which your BBs' reload times can fall in.
13.9s - 17s. BBs fire once per boss cycle. They eat a reload nerf of less than 30%, but 1 out of 3 volleys may miss during the teleport.

17s - 22.5s. The usual best HE guns fall in this bracket, but reload times are unpredictable. The BBs will desync from each other, and a lot of damage is lost due to firing while the special stage is active. The reload nerf is around the full 30%.
22.5s - 26.9s. BBs fire once per two boss cycles. They eat a reload nerf of over 30%, and 1 out of 3 volleys may miss during the teleport.
Warning: We do not recommend using gold plates on fast HE guns just for this battle. They are currently barely used anywhere else.

This fleet won in 9:02 and 8:49 with different gun setups and 20% tech, bad cats, and no submarines. Aegir and Fu Shun had low HP. We will not tell you which gun setup got which time. Because we did not count Helena scans for each battle, we don't know which is better.

With the fast gun setup, the BBs need to have reload times between 13.9s and 17s in order to maintain one salvo for every one of San Diego's cycles. Don't have all three BBs at the upper end of the allowed range. If you do, then BB jamming could cause the last BB to fall behind after several salvos.

With the slow Kearsarge gun setup, the BBs need to have reload times between 22.5s and 26.92s in order to maintain one salvo for every two of San Diego's cycles. Ignore the BBs' usual 0.2s absolute cooldown. Again, don't have all three BBs at the upper end of the allowed range because of jamming.
Use Trafalgar, Aurora, or both if you have them. They will massively buff your BBs and are better than Helena and Fu Shun.
With the +10 fast guns, this fleet won in 4:54 with half tech, the very good Every and Drake cats, and no submarines. With the +13 rainbow guns and otherwise same conditions, the fleet took 5:23.
Same theory as
Mid-End BB
, just with better ships and gear. Use either Trafalgar or Aurora for eva rate.
This fleet won in 4:32 with half tech, Every and a perfect CV cat, and no submarines.

CVs are harder to use against San Diego, so only one top-end example CV fleet is provided. In our experience, Yorktown II is extremely notably weaker in this battle because of her reliance on Kearsarge and Implacable. So this is a non-standard Soyuz-Nakhimov sync. Soyuz Nakhimov is stronger than Yorkii Kearsarge Implacable in general too, not just here. BBs get delayed by 30% while CVs get delayed by 15%. This example uses 9 BB RLD and 21 CV RLD (1 tech + 18 cat talents + 2 Bishamaru skill). Soyuz is 19.59 * 1.3 + 0.2 absolute cooldown, yielding 25.67s. Nakhimov is 22.27 * 1.15 = 25.61s.

If your fleet's main damage is FP, try to do TRP (DDG missiles) damage during the 6s Threat Detection window. If your fleet's main damage is AVI, try to have carriers strike outside the 6s so that the vanguard's FP or TRP damage during the 6s wins. If your fleet's main damage is TRP, it's time to reconsider your life choices. In any case, your main fleet attacks should be close to a 20s reload cycle. If the battle lasts for long enough, and your ships are reloading too fast or too slow, then they'll fall into the 6s window or fall out of it.

SG Radar is required, and it is required to not be on Helena if you use Helena. CVs should be synced tightly and be 20.0s to 20.4s, preferably closer to the 20.4s end of the range. As there should be no AVI damage during the 6s period, the boss Helena should pick FP or TRP to guard against, so she will take full damage from the airstrikes.
The 20.0s is so that they will hit after the Threat Detection period (blue bar from 9:44 to 9:38 in the picture above) by launching after 9:38.5 and having rockets hit after 9:36.5.
The 20.4s is so that over the course of 10 minutes, your CVs won't be so slow as to hit the 6s window near the end of the battle.

Slower is better because there is the 10s of +40% EVA RATE (continuing for 4s after Threat Detection ends). If the CVs are close to 20.0s, then more airstrikes early in the battle will be hitting that 4s period.
Use Sirius, Aurora, and/or Trafalgar if there's a BB(V). They will massively buff your CVs and are better than your Helena because of the boss Helena's +40% EVA RATE.

Barring some shenanigans like giving up one of your main fleet slots for a CV, you will need strong TRP damage every 20s. This effectively means bringing one or two DDGs. You want the DDG missiles to always hit during the 6s window, so the missiles should be 19.8s to 20.0s (recall that both SY-1 have 0.3s volley time and can be subjected to animation trigger time - the calculator handles that, but the in-game display does not). Bringing only one DDG may be inconsistent because your vanguard also does FP damage and missiles can get unlucky with that +40% EVA RATE, so bring two DDGs if you have them.
Warning: Do not use Fu Shun's retrofit skin if she's using 100 kai.

BBs must be slower or faster than 20s by enough. As usual in Challenge Mode, give the slowest BB AFCT/HSFCR, and the other two will catch up after a few salvos. They won't overtake the slow BB unless each reload is more than 1.2s faster than the slow BB's reload or unless they have higher salvo capacity like Alsace or Lion. This will sync the 3 BBs, minimizing the number of salvos in which a BB fires inside the 6s window to trigger FP protection.
This section is for manual only, and only months with a notable manual strategy may have a manual section.

With CVs it is easy, just dump airstrikes outside the 10s window of +40% EVA RATE. With BBs, you probably should still time the DDG missiles, but you can supplement the TRP damage by launching manual torpedoes at the right time. You can also hold the BB salvos so that they don't hit during the 10s of +40% EVA RATE.

This is a 2023 strategy (who uses UvH these days?). Bisz is the slowest BB in this example fleet, so give her AFCT, and the other two will catch up to Bisz after a few salvos. Note that Ulrich must be the flagship so that she doesn't grief the whole fleet by firing all the time.
This setup took 6 to 7 minutes with max tech. It starts slow, like 20 bars of HP in the first 2 minutes, but once the BBs leave the 6s window, the boss HP will decrease much faster.
Calculator link
This fleet won in 6:04 with half tech, 5 DD RLD tech, Every and Drake which are great cats, and no submarines.

DD reload needs to be low enough so that the missiles aren't too fast. If they're oathed, then try using fewer oxytorps or goldburns. Again, it starts slow, but once the BBs leave the 6s window, the boss HP will decrease much faster.
Calculator link

Oaths are exactly as shown, and tech plus cats should give 40 to 47 CV RLD to put this fleet in the 20.0s to 20.4s range. Took over 9 minutes with half tech and cats. This is a rare moment in the Challenge Mode guides where we mixed oaths. As always but especially here, you will have to calculate your own fleet sync if you can't copy this exactly. Hopefully you have better anti-light ships to enable the other fleets below.

Requires 52 to 60 CV RLD if oathed. Took ~5 minutes, but we don't remember whether it was with max tech or half tech.

Yorkii and Implacable should be tightly synced and 20.0s to 20.4s. But as a high end fleet, it should win much faster than in 10 minutes, so 20.7s may be acceptable too. Enterprise is better than a Kearsarge who does 20% main gun damage. Put more survivability if you'll take longer than 5 minutes. Yorkii needs Helena as the third Eagle Union ship.

No strategy needed, just brute force with typical good anti-medium boss fleets. Hope you don't get too many 2+ unbalanced cycles. Try not to use a main fleet that reloads in 20s, although if your account is good enough, you can brute force it with 20s even if every other salvo goes into Enterprise's invincibility.
This section is for manual only, and only months with a notable manual strategy may have a manual section.
Do not use main fleet attacks when the weights are up. Do not kill any weights. Move your vanguard up or down to spread out the damage, or even move to the left so they are mostly out of range.

Any RLD should work. Took 9+ minutes with half tech and mid cats. Not having Plymouth or Bismarck Zwei is quite painful. Duke goes first to debuff the boss and block NJ, and she has approximately the same reload time as Alsace so that Alsace's load capacity doesn't let her pass NJ and Duke. Eldridge slows the boss because Biszwei is missing.

This fleet should win in 4 to 6 minutes with good cats (Every and Drake), half tech, and no subs. Any oath or gear as long as you try somewhat to sync the BBs with each other and they're not stuck at 20s.
Calculator link
, this example did tryhard to get the best firing order of Meck Bisz Lion for the first several salvos.

Any RLD should work. Tech was halved to 20 RLD, 30 AVI, 10 HIT for CVs, and only one cat was used. Cleared in 7 minutes without submarines. Unzen, Tenrai, and Wyvern spam help clear weights (Probably. We didn't watch the battle). Kazagumo buff and Sirius small buff.

This is a CM that can be very annoying due to various sources of lag and RNG. However, do not be scared by the double Hard
. If you time Unicorn precisely, then the Tank check is naturally solved. Or if you bring tanks and Perseus, then Perseus trivializes the timing precision.

You must either bring a vanguard heal that activates every 20s, or have carriers that reload slightly faster than 20s for a screen clear. Toolkits alone will not do the job. The best ways to get the heal are
Primary Healers (Recommended)

Unicorn, who has the benefit of doing more damage and healing than Perseus. Must be timed properly, 19.92s-19.93s probably works for 5-7 minutes, and 19.94s-19.96s probably works for 10 minutes. For a level 125 Unicorn in love,
BF-109G
and
Ryuusei
is 19.95s in-game with 2 RLD tech (also try 3 RLD if 2 doesn't work), or use
HVARcat
and
Ju-87d
with 0 RLD tech.
Do not bring cats with CVL RLD.
Passing the first few stings relies on RNG, because if your vanguard is too close to the boss then they'll get hit before Unicorn heals.

Perseus, who suffers from low damage and lower healing. She struggles to keep a sandwiched Aurora alive, so Eldridge is needed. A Plymouth-Aurora-Eldridge vanguard can survive for 7 minutes, which may not be enough time if your main fleet is weak. Furthermore, if her heal lags less than Elbing's sting, then Perseus can cleanse your vanguard of venom right before Scorpion's Mist (which lasts for 2s) expires. If your ships are moving, they regain the venom by touching Scorpion's Mist.
Minor Healers (not recommended due to how much damage the boss does)
Little Formidable requires >90% HP, so to avoid her being burnt, bring at least one non-concealed main fleet ship, or pray with a full carrier fleet.
Marseillaise for a full-French vanguard.
Boise μ with a level 8 healing skill.
Ognevoy has a 10s heal, but she desyncs after like 5 minutes due to activating 4x as much as Elbing's skill.

Due to a possible bug, most vanguard ships get the +60% damage buff permanently, even if they get healed. Ships who gain, lose, or refresh another source of damageRatioBullet, like Bayard or Bremerton, lose the free +60% damage until the next venom mist. Also, damage may be tight so GLHF if you don't have Aurora.
This section is for manual only, and only months with a notable manual strategy may have a manual section.

If you have fast reflexes, you can use a carrier's airstrike to clear the Fatal Sting barrage before it hits your vanguard. Keep to the left edge of the screen so that you have more time to use the airstrike. Manual should allow you to forgo a healer for more damage.

Oumi, despite being a gold BB, is stronger than all the rainbow BBs for this battle. Elbing often sits still in range of Oumi's secondary guns, so just give her a strong DD gun and you're good to go. The following endscreen speaks for itself. Oumi soloed the boss in 9 minutes with Aurora and Kashino. She was even using a suboptimal non-HE gun to avoid burn damage from making the endscreen damage look less impressive.
This fleet and gear won in 7:25 using half tech, a random gold/purple submarine fleet with random torps and no synergy, and the free cats level 30 Drake and level 25 Every.
Any oaths or tech, just keep the faster black-white shell BB blocked behind the slower BB who is using
AFCT
HSFCR
Same explanation as
High-End BB 1
. But with Ognevoy instead of Unicorn, the fleet has to win faster due to Ognevoy's sync drift and the lack of healing.

Again, any oaths or tech, just keep the faster black-white shell BBs blocked behind the slower BB with AFCT/HSFCR. Removing Aurora and Plymouth is a big loss in DPS, but the extra BB may recover some of it. Marseillaise is required because she heals French ships every 20s. Elbing does a lot of damage, so Brest is required if your battle will go longer than 5 minutes. The third ship can be Le Mars for fleet buff, Mogador for damage, or L'Audacieux for worse Mogador.

For the super lazy people who don't want to time Unicorn, you can use Unicorn and Perseus together. This fleet won in 9:49 with no subs, half tech, a single cat without flame, and no HVARcat or Skyraider.

Forgo healing and use CV screenclear to wipe the sting barrage. This requires carriers to be slightly faster than 20s, which is a high bar for CVs but not CVLs like Unicorn. Due to the 1.5s start of battle delay, if your faster CV has exactly 20.0s reload, the screen clear will happen 0.5s after the boss fires the true damage barrage. If your vanguard is too close to the boss due to RNG, then they'll die in that 0.5s. So you want CVs to reload slightly faster than 20s but not so fast that the CVs strike before the barrage appears.
Or just be a normal person and use the other fleets.

First, read the boss skills if you haven't. You must consistently interrupt Warspite every 20s, and not mentioned is that her charge attack has 30k HP and finishes in 5s. Let "Interrupted" denote your fleet interrupting Warspite by dealing enough damage. Let "Charged" denote the opposite. Generally, an Interrupted causes your main fleet to lose a little HP, and a Charged causes it to lose a LOT of HP. Do not expect to tank two or more Charged.

On average, the charging attack happens every ~20.05s, and Warspite stops for ~8.2s (shown in the chart below) every ~20.45s. Strategies that attempt to take advantage of her stop should consider that timing attacks to her charging attack will become desynced with her stop later in the battle.

One recurring strategy you will find in the following fleets is a BB (excluding extra capacity BBs like Alsace, Lion, Mecklenburg) or Unzen with 20s reload time. After one Charged, Warspite will blind your fleet, preventing torpedoes, airstrikes, and main fleet salvos from launching. The blindness ends around the same time Warspite begins the next charging. Since BBs and Unzen cannot begin reloading the next attack while holding one, they will become synced with Warspite's charging for the rest of the battle.
Unfortunately, this CM is hard. Try your best to copy one of the High-End fleets with Helena, and manual for clearing barrages or hitting stop times if you need to.

The least-effort strategy that may randomly lose even when geared well. The BBs have no sync whatsoever, so they fire at arbitrary times, with UvH offering frequent salvos. Every 20s, pray that at least one BB's salvo partially falls within the 5s charging attack window, and some high-DPS vanguard ships can also help reach the 30k threshold. The fleet is expected to get a few Charged, so you should also pray that your BBs evade enough shells.

In fleets with non-concealed ship(s), Warspite will fire additional AP barrages at your main fleet ships, especially Musashi or the flagship. These barrages chip away your BBs' HP, so it is a DPS race. You could try putting a ship with Flank Defense or Flagship Cover, but it's best if the ship also contributes fleet damage, not just defense.
If you put in more effort, you can try to get Unzen's torpedoes or one of the BBs to have around 20s reload time. Then, the fleet will win more consistently.

Because carriers (except Impero) can store airstrikes, being blinded once by Warspite will not sync the 20s carriers to the charging attack. Therefore, these fleets must rely on the vanguard to deal 30k damage in 5s. If you can get the vanguard damage to work, then ~20s CVs with Helena should produce the fastest possible clear times.
Warning: Unzen's 20.0s to 20.1s (improved) quad mag torpedoes are basically required.

Shown here is an unoathed Unzen with 10 CA RLD tech and a +4 Autoloader yielding a faster reload than 20.0s, but Unzen can be lagged or blocked so 19.98s is suitable. Ideally you should find a sync with one or two oxytorps instead of autoloader. The example could have put two oxytorps, but the autoloader+toolkit was chosen for people who win slower. Shinano, being the slowest of the three carriers, takes defensive auxes to survive for over 5 minutes.
This is a 2023 video using Hakuryuu instead of Amagi(CV), but the idea is identical.

An alternate version with Admiral Nakhimov but requries very high CV RLD and damage. Since there is no other Northern Parliament slow, we need Royal Fortune to provide slow as well. Because of the high CV reload tech, after Royal Fortune leaves, the CVs have caught up to Warspite's stop times.

This page is not just another exp/oil or coin/oil efficiency chart. In fact, it accounts for the boss being blocked by mobs as well as the distribution of Small, Medium, or Large enemy fleets that auto-search will encounter. When choosing a stage to farm, consider the resources you want, between coins, ship experience, and cognitive chips. You should not choose a stage to farm based on its gear blueprint drop.

If you are a new player, you should probably be using one fleet to battle, not two fleets. Put ships in the second fleet, but don't invest resources in it or use it to battle. Your job is to rush to Chapter 9. Before Chapter 9, there is no efficient farming spot in campaign. However, there may be oil-capped events or War Archives that you can access before Chapter 9, like Universe in Unison SP5 in War Archives. These oil-capped stages are far more efficient than Chapters 1 through 8, and they are usually comparable to Chapter 9 or 10 in exp and coin efficiency. If they are too hard for you, then choose the highest campaign stage you can farm because that gives the most ship experience. Also see a real new player guide,
this page is probably not useful for you yet
Once you have access to Chapter 9+ and either one or two fleets, these are some good stages to farm. Read the rest of this page if you want to get details or to make your own decisions.
Tip: Get to 11-1 as soon as possible, because the efficiency spikes for 11-1 and beyond.
For one fleet, 9-2 (leaning to exp) and 10-3 (leaning to coins) provide the best coins and exp overall. For two fleets, the higher the better, but avoid 10-2 and 10-4.

Unless stated otherwise, exp, coins, and chips in this section refer to their per-oil efficiency. Chapter 12 and higher sometimes drop cognitive chips or augment experience stones from clearing rewards. Higher chapters drop more, and stages within the same chapter average the same drops per sortie while costing different oil.
Warning: Some Chapter 13+ stages have very lucrative coin and chip drops, but if you need to bring max-level ships to carry, the exp will be much lower than stated in the tables.
12-4 has respectable coins and exp, and you can drag pretty low level ships through. It's like the default stage to farm, so
the following stages are all compared to 12-4
11-1 has the highest exp of all stages, 9% more exp but zero chips and 19% fewer coins. We recommend to move to Chapter 12+ as soon as possible.
12-1 has 3% more exp and 7% more chips but 10% fewer coins. It is extremely easy to level weak ships.
13-1 has 1% less exp and coins but offers 82% more chips. But note that farming is a tiny part of chip income.
13-4 has 12% more coins and 52% more chips. Watch its difficulty, especially with two out-of-ammo mob battles.
14-4 has 15% more coins and 91% more chips but is much harder than 13-4.

14-1, 15-1, and low-cost 13-1 may enable chip farmers to level every ship to 120 a few months earlier, after several years of grinding. 14-1 and 15-1 give 130% and 156% more chips than 12-4, respectively. If you know 13-1 then you know.
Ship experience and coins per oil efficiency when using TWO fleets.
Perfect Oil
: one sortie's oil cost that the game or wiki pages advertise. It is equal to 10 + MobOilCap * MobCount + BossOilCap * BossCount.
Actual Oil
: one sortie's average simulated oil cost when using auto-search.
Coins/Oil
: average coins per sortie divided by Actual Oil, including clearing rewards and per-battle rewards.
Retire Coins/Oil
: same as Coins/Oil but also includes coins from retiring all ship drops and disassembling all of their equipment.
Total Exp/Oil

: average ship experience per sortie divided by Actual Oil, calculated with 6 ships' worth of experience per battle. Bonuses like MVP, flagship, S/A/B rank, or high morale are not included. For example, if your flagship gets MVP, multiply the exp/oil by 8/6.
Mob Exp/Oil
: how much of the Total Exp/Oil went to the mob fleet.
Boss Exp/Oil
: how much of the Total Exp/Oil went to the boss fleet.
Ship experience and coins per oil efficiency when using ONE fleet.
See
Two Fleets
for what the columns mean. Because you are using one fleet, there are no Mob and Boss Exp/Oil columns, only a Total.

We simulated the auto search algorithm and enemy spawns for each campaign stage 100,000 times using one fleet (Chapters 1 to 15) and 100,000 times using two fleets (Chapters 9 to 15). The server decides what, when, and where enemies spawn. We made several reasonable assumptions, and the simulated results were close enough to empirical results for a few stages chosen for verification. Assumptions:
For
Two Fleets
, the player set Roles for the mob fleet to Escorts and the boss fleet to Flagships.
For
One Fleet
, the player set Roles for his/her primary fleet to All Enemies and the throwaway/statpadding fleet to Standby.
Submarines are not summoned in battle, so their oil cost is zero.
The data found in the client matches what the server uses as parameters for generating enemies.
Fleets spawn in any valid non-blocked tile with equal probability. This includes player fleets, normal enemies, elite enemies, and the boss.
The auto search pathfinding algorithm is done in the client, so we did not need to make an assumption.
See
Coin Details
for further assumptions about clearing rewards and per-battle drops.
For Chapter 8 and below, there is no oil cap, so we assumed 67 oil per battle for a typical max limit broken new player fleet.

When the enemy boss fleet spawns, your "Flagships" or "All Enemies" fleet will go fight it. But what happens if all paths to the boss are blocked by an enemy mob fleet? Your fleet will take the path with the fewest enemy fleets. Notably, if you are using mob and boss fleet roles, your boss fleet will fight the extra enemy mobs plus the enemy boss.
Note: Extra mobs that block the boss have several mostly negative effects on efficiency.
Your boss fleet may lose too much HP before the boss battle, causing a lower rank like A or B, or even outright losing the battle.
Lower mob exp/oil. You pay more oil per sortie for the same amount of mob fleet experience.
Higher boss exp/oil. This is the only good effect but requires that your boss fleet ships all need experience and that every battle is still S-rank.
Significantly lower coins/oil
. You pay more oil per sortie, but the clearing rewards don't increase.

On November 6, 2025, the developers made auto-search go for ammo supply, question mark, and flare tiles. Because going to those tiles changes the mob fleet's position, the distribution and number of enemy fleets you fight have changed for some stages. Turns out the only significant effect is that in 9-4, the average number of mob battles increased by 0.23 for both one fleet and two fleets, which is a nerf in terms of rewards.

The types of tiles that auto-search will pick up are defined by stage. Currently, it goes for ammo then question marks and flares in Chapters 9 and up, and it ignores these tiles in Chapters 8 and below. Here is how auto-search currently works for Chapter 9 and higher.

If the fleet is 3 or more ammo below the maximum ammo, and there is a clear path to an ammo supply tile, then go to the ammo. Clear path means no blocking enemies, so the fleet can get there in one turn.
If there is a clear path to a question mark or flare tile, then go to it.

If there is a boss, then use the boss fleet to go fight it if the path is clear. If there's no clear path, then use the boss fleet to start working on the fewest number of enemy fleets that will clear a path to the boss.
Otherwise, use the mob fleet to fight the nearest enemy.

Note: We have simulated the fleet positions when picking up question mark and flare tiles but not the coins, tech packs, or cargo fleet that can spawn from question marks. Curious readers may check the tables below for how many question mark tiles are picked up.

We put these tables out of the way at the bottom because they are not important to the average reader. The enemy counts and sizes are already included in the important experience and coin efficiency tables above. Curious readers may check out these tables at their convenience.

Chapter 9 and higher have Clearing Rewards that provide coins, gear enhancement plates, dorm food, cognitive chips, and augment module experience after each successful sortie. More oil spent equals more coins from clearing rewards, up to the oil cap. All results for Chapter 9+ on this page assume your fleets are expensive enough to reach oil cap. The clearing reward coin count for each stage is taken from this
CN wiki source
, but we do not condone their data collection methods. Data collected by EN players are close enough to these numbers.

Each battle drops some coins and has a chance to drop a ship. The averages are copied from the same CN wiki source. We assumed that for stages with multiple bosses, the non-final bosses have the same drop rates as event elite enemies. We further assumed that the average coins per retired ship, including gear, is 20 coins. The coins per ship actually depends on the probability distribution of different ships in each stage, but a blanket assumption of 20 coins should be close enough to truth. Again, data collected by EN players are close enough to these numbers.

Gold Single 113mm vs Blue Single 76mm, which is better? The answer isn't immediately obvious because the Blue Single 76mm reloads faster, and the whole point of using one of these two guns is to shoot more.
Image
Base Reload
Range
Cost
"Free"
FP
Damage
Armor Mod
Shell Range
Conclusion first in case you don't want to read.
First, make sure the ship actually wants one of these guns.
See
Quick Gear Guide
for a list of ships.
New player or haven't finished the priority gear lab crafts? Blue 76.
Don't care about minmaxing? Either gun.
RLD thresholds.
Goldburn
is always a safe choice for increasing RLD. Autoloader or Oxytorp depends on your ship's survival.
290 <= RLD or preferably 291 <= RLD? Gold 113.
270 <= RLD <= 289? Either gun.
RLD <= 253? Gold 113.
270 RLD is an untested spot. The threshold may be slightly higher or lower, but it doesn't matter much.
Bonus: You want to pay 120 gold plates for a 2% damage bonus to a single vanguard ship? +13 Gold 113.

Note: RLD stat is calculated as the white plus green plus yellow number on the ship screen. Skill percentage multipliers are applied after, but very few ships have that. The RLD is 310 in the following example.

Vanguard guns operate at a frequency of 10 Hertz. That is, they attempt to fire 10 times per second. A gun that reloads in 0.45s and the same gun that reloads in 0.47s are identical in reality because they are both rounded up to 0.50s. Meanwhile, a gun that reloads in 0.50s is unpredictable, because it can go at 0.50s or 0.60s randomly depending on device lag. Other factors that affect vanguard firing rate, such as animation trigger time, are outside the scope of this article.

From a pure minmaxing perspective, the only advantage of the Blue 76 over Gold 113 is its reload time. Everything else is worse. Hence, Blue 76 only has a chance to beat Gold 113 if it crosses a 10 Hertz threshold. In most maxed out destroyers' cases, that threshold is 0.50s. In the following tests, we explored different reload values on the ship to see whether Blue 76 can beat Gold 113 at certain reload values.

We tested the two guns using these setups on an oathed Z52. The torpedo was unequipped to reduce variance because her torpedo salvos are irrelevant to the test between the guns and barrages. An oathed Z52 with 200 affinity has 245 base RLD, and +10 Autoloader takes it to 280. For DD RLD tech values ranging from 0 to 27, our Z52 had 280 to 307 RLD. Because Blue 76 reloads faster, another option dropping the Autoloader for the All Work, All Play Robot was tested.

We battled Scharnhorst META showdown using this Z52 with various settings of DD RLD tech and both guns. Each gun and reload was tested several times, with the central Gold 113 threshold of 290 and 291 RLD being tested 10 times each to get a more confident average.

The main fleet consisted of Vestal and Zuihou for healing without adding damage bias, plus Chaser with double ASW planes. The other vanguard ships were Jeanne and Eldridge, both equipped with anti-submarine weapons to reduce variance on Z52's ASW damage. Also note that Scharnhorst META is medium armor, and Blue 76 is slightly favored against medium.
Note: The gold and light blue line (non-WorkPlay) lose 7 FP from Autoloader for the data points below 279 RLD.
Note: Results may vary slightly depending on device lag.

Gold 113, represented by the gold line, has a large jump between 290 and 291 RLD. At 291 and above, it is clearly superior to Blue 76. Below that, it is similar to Blue 76 for any RLD stat and any auxiliary gear.

Why such a large jump between 290 and 291 RLD? Although the game shows 0.50s for both due to rounding, that's where Gold 113 goes from 0.5000816527s to 0.4994417526s reload time. What a coincidence!! It's also not completely flat on either side due to the randomness in device lag. So 292 is better than 291, and 289 is worse than 290 RLD. Similarly, for Blue 76, there is a large difference between 253 and 254 RLD. But what happened to Gold 113 between 265 and 272 RLD? There's no reload time breakpoint there. We currently don't have any ideas to explain it.

Final note: Compared to a torpedo boat like Shimakaze, Z52 certainly does have a stronger main gun slot that can benefit from Gold 113's damage. Against light, medium, and heavy bosses respectively, Z52 with +10 Gold 113 has her main gun accounting for 10%, 5%, and 2% of her total damage respectively. We did not calculate Shimakaze, but her anti-heavy damage is probably less than 1% main gun. For torpedo ships, the Gold 113's damage advantage is suppressed, leaving nearly only the range and reload difference. So there is a possibility that Blue 76 is better for them at more RLD values.
This is the submarine reload tool featuring the
correct
formula, unlike
this widely-recommended user page
on the wiki. A similarly-structured table with the correct values is provided here so you may see the differences.

Formula and Theory
Disclaimers and Assumptions
In a real battle, the enemy can be out of range even if the submarine is ready to fire. That means the next reload often gets delayed for Bidder/G7e.
Hence, do not assume she will fire that many salvos by meeting the minimum RLD requirement.
Assume the submarine equips the same torpedo in both slots.
The calculator does not make accommodations for weird or poverty cases like gear below +10, non-100 or 200 affinity, purple oxygen, non-maxed skills, or low level submarines.
Device-specific processing speed or lag may shift volley times by 0.1s or more.
The calculator pessimistically uses the longest delays caused by animation time we have observed across multiple devices, while the table shows the RLD range from shortest to longest delay.
See
Torpedo Mount Cycle
for these thresholds.

Usage instructions are below the calculator. This is the best submarine reload calculator on the market (and it's free!). For damage estimations to learn the effects of oxytorps, tech, and cats on damage, consult
AL Calculator
by MrLar. For reload times of non-submarines, also use that calculator.
The general workflow is:
Select the Preset Ship.
Select the affinity. For <100 or oathed and <200, you're out of luck and should type in the Base RLD manually.
Base reload assumes level 125. But Level 120 is close enough, usually only a difference of 1 or 2. Type it manually if you care.
Add your cat talents and gear like Oxytorps.
Skill percentages should be covered by the Preset, but there are exceptions like a non-full wolfpack.
Base and Add Oxygen should be covered by the Preset.
Do not add Snorkel oxygen.
Checking the OpSi box will add 20 oxygen. If you use one but not the other cat in Operation Siren, uncheck the box and type the value in Add.
Warning: The non-Snorkel loadouts do NOT assume that Oxytorp is used in place of it. You need to manually add 10 RLD for +10 or 13 RLD for +13 Oxytorp in the "Add (gear/cats)" box.
This calculator shows numbers for six gear loadouts.
Salvos: How many salvos. For example, 1.75 salvos of Bidders * 4 mounts * 3 torpedoes = 21 torpedoes total.
Margin: How much time is left over after completing that many salvos. Lower margin means less likely to complete that many salvos.
RLD for next: The Final Reload stat needed to complete the next full salvo.

Color shows how much extra RLD from cats and oaths is needed to reach the upper threshold, starting from a base of Level 125, Love affinity. Gear is assumed to be Snorkel/Hull or +10 Oxytorp/Hull for Bidder/G7e, or +10 Oxytorp/Snorkel or +10 Oxytorp/Oxytorp for Type 95 Kai. Percent reload skills are already considered.
Green = 0
Yellow = 1 to 20
Orange = 21 to 40
Red = 41 to max
Purple = impossible even with max RLD cats, 200 affinity, and +13 Oxytorps.
Compare this table to the
wiki user page

, though we excluded Mark 16 because it's irrelevant. The most important difference is that our formula is correct (discrepancies may occur due to device-specific lag) while theirs is not. For a real example, it says Albacore needs 154 RLD for Bidder without Snorkel, but our Albacore tested in game with a +10 Oxytorp and single Edelweiss 20 RLD fired the full 24 torpedoes outside of Operation Siren (total 126 RLD). Don't bother submitting feedback because that author hates us and automatically disparages any proof or work if he suspects it was from us.
The
Subaquatic Secrets Verified (SSV)

Google Sheet contains simulated torpedo counts and hit rates against moving bosses. The simulation includes random movement, animation trigger time, weapon queues, and all that stuff. Sample videos are linked in the sheet.

This sheet can provide some context on how important targeting range is. The submarine in the top position suffers a lot with Bidder or G7e. Barely meeting the minimum reload requirement is almost never good enough.
Basic definitions:
is 2 for G7e and Type 95 Kai or 3 for Bidder.
is 0.7s for G7e and Type 95 Kai or 0.6s for Bidder.
Volley = fire 1 mount of
torpedoes.
Salvo = fire 1 volley from all mounts. All max limit broken subs in game currently have 2 torpedo slots x 2 torpedo mounts = 4 mounts.
After you press the button to summon subs, each sub behaves in the following way unless her skills do something special like surface and dive again.
Spawn at a fixed coordinate off-screen and swim to the attacking coordinate, which depends on Pressure-Resistant Hull, the specific sub, and the battle field.
Begin consuming oxygen, using skills, firing torpedoes, and randomly moving within a box centered on her attacking coordinate.
When oxygen reaches zero, the submarine surfaces. She can use both torpedoes and guns.
After
seconds have passed, she begins retreating. She can no longer fire weapons but can finish a volley that began before the retreat.
There is a delay of 1 weapon cycle, or 0.1s, between when the sub starts consuming oxygen and when her weapons can first look for targets. Thus, the total time a sub has to
begin
volleys is
Note: Most submarines have an
of 5s. The exceptions are already included in the calculator's Preset Ships.
Pretend the submarine only has 1 mount equipped with Bidder. This is what the mount does.
Find valid target in range.
Begin an animation on the sub's chibi sprite.
After
seconds, fires the weapon.
Repeat
times: wait
seconds, then fire 1 torpedo.
Take
to reload the next salvo.
Reloading a mount takes
You can find the
on

or

, for example 21.81s for Bidder.
We care about the

, which is the time from the beginning of Step 1 to the end of Step 4. However, this is where the game can randomly and inconsistently apply an extra delay. The length of the delay is correlated to the device and the sub's
, but it is not consistent.

content.snippet:
volley_time = round_to_next_tenth(trigger_duration + torpedo_count * delay)
volley_time = random_trigger_delay + torpedo_count * delay

content.text: According to our observations,
The game only attempts to find valid targets in range 10 times per second. So for one mount, the time between beginning a salvo and beginning the next salvo is calculated as
Now what happens when the submarine has 4 torpedo mounts? If all of them are ready to fire, the first one fires first. While the first one is firing for
, the others cannot.
Each mount tracks its own reload progress. While the second mount is firing, the third and fourth mounts are blocked from firing. But the first mount is already on its reload cycle.

So in the end, the multiple mounts do not affect each others' salvo times past the first salvo assuming they are all derived from the same equipment. But the mount count is indeed important in determining partial salvos. The submarine could begin retreating while she's firing her second mount. That means she will finish her second mount but not fire her third and fourth mounts in the last salvo.

In the following example of I-404 with Bidders, Snorkel, and 162 RLD, she begins retreating at time represented by the purple line. Notice that the time between the first yellow torpedo line and the thirteenth torpedo is the
, just over 21s, and this
also holds between the fourth and sixteenth, seventh and nineteenth, and so on.
Putting it all together, we want to calculate the
needed to fully complete
salvos within the
. In the following equations, we ignore the inequalities and round_to_next_tenth's, and we just add RLD one by one at the end until the inequality holds true.

content.snippet:
total_time = time_from_first_salvo_start_to_last_salvo_start + time_from_last_salvo_start_to_last_mount
total_time = cycle_time * (target_salvos - 1) + volley_time * (mounts - 1)
total_time = (volley_time + target_reload_time) * (target_salvos - 1) + volley_time * (mounts - 1)
total_time = volley_time * (target_salvos - 1) + target_reload_time * (target_salvos - 1) + volley_time * (mounts - 1)
total_time = volley_time * (target_salvos + mounts - 2) + target_reload_time * (target_salvos - 1)
total_time - volley_time * (target_salvos + mounts - 2) = target_reload_time * (target_salvos - 1)
target_reload_time = (total_time - volley_time * (target_salvos + mounts - 2)) / (target_salvos - 1)

target_reload_time = base_weapon_reload_time * (200 / (100 + reload_stat))^0.5
(target_reload_time / base_weapon_reload_time)^2 = 200 / (100 + reload_stat)
200 / (target_reload_time / base_weapon_reload_time)^2 = 100 + reload_stat
reload_stat = 200 * (base_weapon_reload_time / target_reload_time)^2 - 100
reload_stat = 200 * (base_weapon_reload_time / ((total_time - volley_time * (target_salvos + mounts - 2)) / (target_salvos - 1)))^2 - 100
reload_stat = 200 * (base_weapon_reload_time * (target_salvos - 1) / (total_time - volley_time * (target_salvos + mounts - 2)))^2 - 100
reload_stat = 200 * (base_weapon_reload_time * (target_salvos - 1) / (total_time - (random_trigger_delay + torpedo_count * delay) * (target_salvos + mounts - 2)))^2 - 100
reload_stat = 200 * (base_weapon_reload_time * (target_salvos - 1) / (total_oxygen / 10 + attack_duration - 0.1 - (random_trigger_delay + torpedo_count * delay) * (target_salvos + mounts - 2)))^2 - 100

content.text: Behold, the final* equation. This spits out a reload stat that is lowballed by up to 10 RLD, so it may not be the final answer. We then need to plug it into the complete salvo formula with the rounding-to-tenths part, and increase the reload one by one until the number of complete salvos ticks up to
Chapter 15 enemy smokescreens.
Every 30s, two Mass-Produced Kagerou Class spawn off screen. The first spawn is at 2:42 for (all? I didnt check) chapter 15 battles.

These Mass-Produced Kagerou Class slowly move left to eventually crash into your main fleet. They do not have to be killed for the battle to end. They have 40 SPD with a 0.4 multiplier for 16 effective SPD.
After spawning, each Mass-Produced Kagerou Class spawns a tiny smokescreen on itself, every 0.8s, for 6 times.

After each smokescreen spawns, it expands over 3s, with a quadratic rate of expanstion, to around 21x56 size (can be smaller if your potato device skips calculation frames). Then it disappears after 12s more, for a total duration of 15s.
Enemies who touched the smokescreen get aim bias, not an EVA rate buff.

Enemies in smoke, enemies in night weather, and allied vanguard/subs in night weather have an aim bias represented by a bar above the unit. Aim bias causes the opposing side's attacks to be aimed randomly within a square centered on the unit, and the square's size depends on the fullness of the bar and other factors. On this page, "concealment" refers to aim bias of vanguard ships, submarines, and enemy ships, not to main fleet concealment.

Enemies that leave the smokescreen are Exposed, removing aim bias and pausing the decay. Re-entering the smokescreen within 3 seconds resumes aim bias but does not reset it to max. If the enemy does not re-enter a smokescreen within 3 seconds of being Exposed, the aim bias will start at max when the enemy enters a smokescreen.
The aim bias bar decays with a speed based on complex formulas. Aim bias is measured in "units" and decay speeds are in units per second.

content.snippet: combinedSpeed = decaySpeedRatio * maxAimBias + decaySpeedFog + decaySpeedHit + decaySpeedRadar

content.text: In Chapter 14, when you wipe an enemy wave, there are no enemies on screen.
But this is 0 at the beginning of the battle even though enemies haven't spawned yet.

While battling enemy fleets that are located inside the foggy weather on a Chapter 14 sortie map, all allied and enemy ships get aim bias decay speed -0.15, meaning that all ships stay concealed for longer.

Applies in both Chapters 14 and 15. The HIT stat of the ship with the highest HIT stat on either side (friend or foe, excluding support carriers) will affect the rate of decay of the opposing side's aim bias. Submarines are only affected by the highest HIT stat among the opposing side's DD, CL, and DDG(V). This effect is capped to 300 HIT on the highest-HIT ship.
Each ship equipped with a radar-like gear (excluding support carriers) makes the enemy aim bias decay
very slightly
quicker. Applies in both Chapters 14 and 15. Two radar-like gear on one ship only counts as one.

content.text: Most fighters and a few other airplanes have passive interception, henceforth referred to as "interception." Look at the fire rate (FR) of an airplane in your depot or on your ship. If it has a drop-down that says "Intercept RoF," then that airplane can intercept.

As with other weapons, carriers' RLD stat affects Intercept RoF. In flight, the anti-air effectiveness of the intercepting aircraft depends on the mother carrier's level, current stats (AVI and RLD), and current airplane slot efficiency. Technically, HIT and LUCK matter too, but because enemy airplanes have only 1 EVA, differences in HIT and LUCK make less than a 1% difference through crit rate.
Note: Interception works entirely independently of carriers' main airstrikes and skill (barrage) airstrikes.

When an enemy airplane is doing a strafing run (in PvE, it's going from right to left) and your interceptor is off cooldown, the carrier launches the interceptor. When one plane is launched, it puts the carrier's interception queue in cooldown for 0.5s, preventing all other intercepting planes from launching during this time. In effect, this means that each plane launches 0.6s after the previous if it is ready. For example, an Illustrious with Flapjack, Focke-Wulf 190 A-5, and Wyvern will launch 8 planes (3 Flapjacks, 3 fw190a5, and 2 Wyverns) with 0.6s between each, taking 4.2s to finish. After around 3s more, the first Flapjack to launch will finish its ~7s cooldown. Each airplane has its own cooldown, and each carrier has her own interception queue cooldown.
Then, the airplanes use their guns to shoot enemy airplanes.
In Chapter 15, support carriers use their levels, stats (AVI and RLD), and fighter efficiencies. Skills, cats, and crossfleet buffs do NOT take effect.

The support carriers are spawned at the flagship's normal position (if you put Odin as flagship, you might see airplanes appearing from thin air/water), but they cannot be seen, interacted with, or killed. They launch intercepting fighters and only intercepting fighters.
Warning: Wyvern, Breguet, and all other DB/TBs do NOT intercept when equipped on a support carrier. They only act as AVI statsticks.

Unlike normal carriers which check for enemy planes, support carriers launch their intercepting fighters as soon as they're off cooldown. For example, around 8s after the start of battle, an Illustrious with Flapjack, Focke-Wulf 190 A-5, and Wyvern will launch 3 flapjacks with 0.6s between each, wait around 1s more, then launch 3 fw190a5 with 0.6s between each.
Note: The coordinate system is 3D. X is horizontal left to right, Z is vertical bottom to top of your screen, and Y is mostly unimportant.
when the airplane is first launched, it is unable to attack for 1.5s. It chooses targetZ as a random Z coordinate in the middle three fifths of the vanguard movement field.
while the airplane is alive,
X-speed is constant and depends on the Plane Speed advertised on the equipment.
Z-speed is equal to 0.5 in the direction from the airplane's Z coordinate to its targetZ.
If the targetZ has been reached, then roll another random targetZ.
Thus, airplanes zigzag vertically while flying horizontally across the screen.
